Japan’s Many Socioeconomic Issues

Why Japan is slowly killing itself.

Daniel Goldman
Apr 6

So Trump has backed off his threat to close down the southern border, at least for now. That’s good. It was a stupid idea, but it’s not a surprising one coming from Trump. Sadly, the United States immigration policy needs a great deal of reform. But the way much of the world speaks of the US, you’d think that we’re exceptional in our abuses. We’re not. And Japan is a perfect example, which is suffering from both an immigration policy crisis and a cultural crisis.

< Master Index|Cultural Politics|

I’ve written a few articles on the topic before. One of those articles was from a financial perspective, and another was from a more social perspective. I’d like to combine a lot of the information from both of those topics here, in order to give an overview of the social and economic issues that Japan is facing, and how these two issues are really in many ways one and the same.

Japan is a tech savvy nation with a lot of large conglomerates. It has a long history of successful business, with its oldest continuously operating business being Kongō Gumi, a Japanese construction company that was in continuous operation from 578 C.E. until its absorption by another company in 2016. Or in other words, a business that has been in operation for over 1,400 years! And yet Japan’s economy is faltering. The reason for this has to do largely with its population and its refusal to open its borders. As I have said before, I am a proponent of “free market immigration.” If Japan opens its borders, it would produce a huge buying opportunity.

Instead, Japan has been experiencing a significant population decline. According to the Washington Post, “the 2010 census showed a population of 128,057,352, but the 2015 figure…shows just 127,110,000.” Furthermore, according to PEW research, Japan’s population is expected to decline by upwards of 15% by 2050. As importantly, because of a low birth rate, Japan’s population is old, and getting older.

People think that US immigration policy is bad, and it is, but the US doesn’t hold a candle to Japanese immigration policies. Japan has long held a policy of limited immigration and engagement with foreign nations. From the early 17th through the mid-19th century, Japan had an almost totally closed off nation, with deep penalties for anyone who left or entered the nation. While such restrictions are far less severe these days, immigration to Japan is still very difficult. Besides the difficulty in entering the country, and remaining there, Japan does not recognize dual citizenship. This means that any person, who wishes to gain citizenship in Japan, must renounce citizenship elsewhere.

Unseen Japan wrote a short piece on Naomi Osaka’s decision to finally hand in her Japanese passport. Osaka is a pro tennis player and represents Japan. But she chose to hand in her Japanese passport. It’s just one example among many, showcasing how Japan’s unwillingness to allow dual citizenship is hurting itself. Sure, if the economy were booming, a lot of people might choose Japan over rival citizenship options, but with a decaying economy, those who have resources and who want to do their best with them are likely going to keep leaving, resulting in an even greater drain on the country.

This population decline, along with a shift to urban lifestyles, has left villages abandoned and has negatively impacted the economy. Japan’s GDP peaked in 2012, at a little over 6T USD. Only in the last couple of years has the economy started to grow again, and even then, GDP for 2017 was below $5T, almost 20% lower than the 2012 high. (Trading Economics)

The negative impact on the economy has also had a negative impact on sociological conditions. During economic downturns, suicide rates can increase, and Japan saw just that. The long-term economic stagnation in the country is one of the reasons why Japan has the highest suicide rates in the world. In fact, suicide rates were so high for a time that they dwarfed the combined suicide and homicide rate in the United States (Suicide in Japan).

So the Japanese immigration policy, and related policies, have had a number of negative impacts on Japan. It is true that in 2016, Japan started work on some minor reform. According to the East Asia Forum, minor changes include an increase in temporary workers. But this reform just isn’t enough. It will do next to nothing in terms of filling the gap in available labor, created by the aging population.

While Japan is just one example, it is an example of another first world country with so many issues that one might wonder why so much of the world focuses on the United States. And why do Americans think that America is so much worse than other first world nations? Honestly, I think it has something to do with American exceptionalism. We are so convinced that we are exceptional, that we even believe that we are exceptionally evil.

Modified from one of my Seeking Alpha articles.

Omiai

Only part of Japan’s population decline problem is directly associated with its strict immigration policy. There’s another social element. Omiai is the tradition of arranged marriages in Japan, and it was a very large component of finding relationships in Japan, up until the 60s. Indeed, according to Typing the Knot, just half a century ago, around 70% of all marriages were arranged marriages, but by 1998, that number fell to less than 10%. Now, whether arranged marriages are “good” or not is beyond the scope of this article. There are benefits and there are negatives.

Along with the highly restrictive immigration policy, I argue that the move away from the omiai system is partially to blame for the declining birth rates in Japan. Now, I admit that I have little evidence for what I am about to suggest. This is mostly conjecture, but it is reasonable, and can be tested through surveys and other sociology techniques.

The United States had an approximate birthrate of 12.5 per 1000. Japan, on the other hand, had a birth rate of only 7.8 per thousand. (World Factsheet) According to surveys on the topic, a lot of young adults in Japan simply do not want children. This attitude towards procreation helps to explain why birth rates are so low, but what we really need to know is why the attitude exists in the first place. The shift away from omiai provides such an explanation: because arranged marriages were a primary means in which couples were united, there was no culture of dating. Westernization brought with it a move away from arranged marriage, but it takes far more fully adjust to dating as the primary method of finding relationships. To be honest, even for those people, in nations where dating has long been the norm, it can still be difficult. It is not surprising that the Japanese people would have trouble adapting to a completely different system of finding relationships.

Again, this is not the entire reason behind the decline in Japanese population growth, but it does make sense that it is a component of it. Therefore, in order to combat the declining population, either arranged marriages will have to start becoming more common again, or a “culture of dating” will need to be heavily adopted in Japan. Going back to the topic of immigration, I do think that opening the border would help a lot. Immigrants would bring with them such a culture, and would increase population, not only directly by their movement into the country, but also by increasing the birth rate.

Adapted from “Omiai, Why the Japanese Population is Declining”
